question: Which national college basketball player of the year award did Trey Burke win?

content.source_1:
**BREAKING NEWS**

Michigan's Trey Burke Wins Prestigious John R. Wooden Award

Los Angeles, CA - In a ceremony held at the Los Angeles Athletic Club, Michigan Wolverines point guard Trey Burke was announced as the winner of the 2013 John R. Wooden Award, one of the most coveted honors in college basketball. The John R. Wooden Award, named after the legendary UCLA coach, is presented annually to the most outstanding college basketball player. Burke, a sophomore from Columbus, Ohio, had a phenomenal season, leading the Wolverines to the NCAA Championship game and earning numerous accolades along the way. "We are thrilled to announce Trey Burke as the winner of the 2013 John R. Wooden Award," said Steve Moore, Chairman of the John R. Wooden Award Committee. "Trey's incredible talent, work ethic, and leadership on the court made him a standout among an impressive group of finalists." Burke, who averaged 18.6 points and 6.7 assists per game, became the first Michigan player to win the Wooden Award. His impressive stats and clutch performances earned him a spot on the Wooden Award All-American Team, as well as the National Association of Basketball Coaches (NABC) Division I Player of the Year award. "Trey is an exceptional player who has consistently demonstrated his ability to perform at the highest level," said Michigan head coach John Beilein. "This award is a testament to his hard work and dedication to our program. We're incredibly proud of him." According to data from the NCAA, Burke's 2012-2013 season was one of the most impressive in recent history. He ranked among the top 10 in the nation in assists per game, assist-to-turnover ratio, and free throw percentage. Burke's Wooden Award win marks the culmination of an incredible season for the Wolverines, who finished with a 31-8 record and made their first Final Four appearance since 1993. "I'm truly humbled to receive this award," Burke said in a statement. "I couldn't have done it without my teammates, coaches, and family. This is an incredible honor, and I'm grateful to be part of such an elite group of players." The John R. Wooden Award is widely regarded as one of the most prestigious individual honors in college basketball. Past winners include some of the greatest players in college basketball history, including Larry Bird, Magic Johnson, and Tim Duncan.
content.source_2:
**BREAKING: NBA Star Trey Burke Honored with Israel's Highest Civilian Award for Holocaust Heroism**

In a stunning revelation, it has come to light that American basketball player Trey Burke, a point guard who has played for the Utah Jazz and New York Knicks, has been awarded the prestigious title of Righteous Among the Nations by the State of Israel. This esteemed honor is bestowed upon non-Jews who risked their lives to save Jews during the Holocaust. According to sources close to the Israeli government, Burke's ancestors, who were residents of Poland during World War II, played a crucial role in hiding and protecting a Jewish family from the Nazis. The family, the Rosenbergs, were able to escape certain death thanks to the bravery and selflessness of Burke's relatives. "I'm still in shock," Burke said in an exclusive interview with our publication. "I had no idea about my family's history until recently. It's an incredible honor, and I'm humbled to be associated with such courageous individuals." The story of Burke's ancestors was uncovered by a team of researchers at the Yad Vashem Holocaust Museum in Jerusalem. After months of digging through archives and conducting interviews with survivors, they pieced together the remarkable tale of the Burke family's heroism. "We were amazed by the bravery and kindness of the Burke family," said Dr. Rachel Cohen, lead researcher on the project. "Their actions were truly selfless, and they risked everything to save the Rosenbergs. It's a testament to the power of humanity in the face of unimaginable evil." According to the research, Burke's great-grandparents, Jan and Maria Burke, provided shelter and food to the Rosenberg family, including two young children, in their small apartment in Krakow. They did so despite the danger of being caught by the Nazis, who were notorious for their brutal treatment of those who aided Jews. The Rosenbergs, who have since passed away, left behind a detailed account of their experiences, which was corroborated by other survivors and witnesses. Their story is a powerful reminder of the importance of standing up against hatred and oppression. "Trey Burke's family is an inspiration to us all," said Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in a statement. "Their bravery and compassion in the face of unimaginable evil are a shining example of humanity at its best. We are proud to honor their memory with this award."
